qas.question: What Arabic term did the Umayyad caliphs use to refer to themselves?
Where was the Abbasid court based?
What is the Arabic term for kingship?
What was the tradition Arabic title used by caliphs?
What does khalifat Allah translate to in English?
Who has a positive reception from later Islamic historians?
What is a term for kingship that has connotations of freedom?
Who calls the Umayyads a true caliphate?
Who saw a need to share religious power with the religious scholars?
What histories were written outside the Abbasid court?

context: The <b5_0>Umayyads<b5_0/> have met with a largely negative reception from <b7_0>later Islamic historians<b7_0/>, who have accused them of promoting a kingship (<a2_0><b6_0>mulk<b6_0/><a2_0/>, a term with connotations of tyranny) instead of a true caliphate (khilafa). In this respect it is notable that the Umayyad caliphs referred to themselves not as <a3_0>khalifat rasul Allah<a3_0/> ("successor of the messenger of God", the title preferred by the tradition), but rather as <a0_0>khalifat Allah<a0_0/> ("<a4_0>deputy of God<a4_0/>"). The distinction seems to indicate that the <b8_0>Umayyads<b8_0/> "regarded themselves as God's representatives at the head of the community and saw no need to share their religious power with, or delegate it to, the emergent class of religious scholars." In fact, it was precisely this class of scholars, based largely in Iraq, that was responsible for collecting and recording the traditions that form the primary source material for the history of the Umayyad period. In reconstructing this history, therefore, it is necessary to rely mainly on sources, such as the histories of <b9_0>Tabari and Baladhuri<b9_0/>, that were written in the Abbasid court at <a1_0>Baghdad<a1_0/>.
